data.title: Blog â€“ Arcade Odysseus
data.text:
Friday the 19th of April, 2024, 8.05 pm. Iâ€™d just left Arcade Club, Blackpool â€“ four hours before it was due to close. There were no problems â€“ no crises.

Iâ€™d enjoyed my soiree. I was fed, watered, arcaded and impressed. I certainly wasnâ€™t tired. So why did I leave?

I had a schedule to follow, of course. It was time for the second leg of my Arcade Overload tour. Destination: Arcade Club, Bury!!!

Ten minutes later, Iâ€™d selected my destination on Google Maps, slapped my phone into its car bracket, and eased down the slipway onto the M55. With the evening being so mild and clear, I was surprised to find the road so quiet. Pleasantly surprised. What wasnâ€™t quite so pleasant was realising that most of the other drivers were weaving along at 120mph without bothering to indicate! Mirror, signal, manoeuver, people!

Thereâ€™s no denying it. Compared to the M74, Lancashireâ€™s roards are a bit on the â€˜livelyâ€™ side. As the clock ticked towards 9 pm, and it became properly dark, the M61 was suddenly nose to tailâ€¦ at 70 mph! Iâ€™ve rarely been more pleased to get off the motorway.

Within half an hour of pulling into my hotel, Iâ€™d dropped my luggage (not a euphamism), hit the pavement, and powered-walked the final mile to Cork Street, and Ela Mill.

As the clock struck ten, I was in and arcading again. And not just for the next two hours. The whole long Saturday shift was stretching out in front of me. Was it worth it? Well, letâ€™s find out!

In todayâ€™s blogpost, weâ€™ll take a look at what â€“ for me â€“ is the epicentre of the retro gaming world â€“ Europeâ€™s largest video arcade â€“ at Arcade Club, Bury. Weâ€™ll cover all the bases â€“ how to get there, where to stay, the other local retro-gaming â€˜attractionsâ€™, and â€“ most important of all â€“ how to prepare yourself to make the most of your visit to â€˜The Clubâ€™.

Getting there

Welcome to Bury, Lancashire â€“ famous for its black pudding, its bus station and its Bobbies. Bury was the birthplace of Sir Robert Peel, the British prime minister who introduced the modern police force â€“ explaining why, even today, police officers are sometimes known as â€˜Bobbiesâ€™!

Getting to Bury by public transport is easy enough if you live nearby. Lancashire, generally, is well-served by local busses, with greater Manchester â€“ of which Bury is part â€“ also enjoying an excellent tram network.

However, if you hail from further afirth â€“ like what I do â€“ your options are a bit more limited.

If youâ€™re travelling from Scotland, youâ€™d be forgiven for thinking that a train to Manchester was the obvious best choice. Now, Iâ€™m a big fan of longer train journeys. I love the way they almost force you to relax â€“ giving you the confinement, but also the space you need to read, listen to some music, stare out the window, or just snooze. Iâ€™ve made that journey a few times in the past. But in 2024, it simply doesnâ€™t add up.

For one thing, over the past 5 years or so, the trains from Edinburgh (or Glasgow) to Manchester have pretty much doubled in price. These days, youâ€™ll be lucky to get change out of Â£100 for a return ticket. And thatâ€™s not the only catch. You want to be travelling south. But once you get off the train at Manchester, you then need to find your way to the right tram stop, buy another ticket and head back north to Bury. Itâ€™s a nice enough journey, but itâ€™ll add time and expense to your trip.

As much as we might want to do our bit for the environment, thereâ€™s no escaping the fact that the easiest, quickest and cheapest way to get to Bury from the frozen north â€“ even if youâ€™re travelling on your own â€“ is to drive.

If thatâ€™s not possible, or youâ€™re determined to use public transport, youâ€™ll have to invest some serious time in planning the logistics. Your best bet is to get an advance return on the train to Preston, then use local buses to get to Bury via Bolton. At the moment, local buses in England cost no more than Â£2, which could add up to quite a saving. Of course, the big drawback to that way of doing things is time. You might spend longer hinginâ€™ aboot bus stations waiting for connections than travelling. But at least itâ€™ll take you back to being a teenager!

If youâ€™re coming from the southâ€¦ commiserations!

Donâ€™t worry, though, getting to The Club wonâ€™t be quite so awkward.

Where to stay

There is no shortage of places to stay in and around Bury. Digs can be found to cater for all tastes â€“ and wallets â€“ especially if you donâ€™t mind a bit of a commute.

Most of the budget hotel chains have locations in or near the town itself. If youâ€™re driving, and not planning on drinking, thereâ€™s a Travelodge at the retail park 10 minutes to the south. Last time I checked, it didnâ€™t do food. But there is a massive supermarket within walking distance.

If, like me, you donâ€™t want to be getting back in the car again before your 5-hour odyssey home, youâ€™ll want something a bit more central. Something walkable. One of my favourites is the Premier Inn on Knowsley Street, just over 20-minutesâ€™ walk away from The Club. If you avoid the major holiday weekends, and book in advance, you can usually get a family room for around Â£40 a night â€“ give or take a tenner! They do an excellent buffet breakfast â€“ for an extra charge â€“ which is the ideal way to stock up on the nutrients and energy youâ€™ll need to see you through a hard dayâ€™s retro-gaming! One thing to watch out for, though, is the parking. The closest secure parking is right next to the hotel, but itâ€™s independently-owned. And the overnight fees have recently gone up to Â£12.50. Swings and roundabouts ðŸ˜¦

Retro-gaming shops

Bury might be an old market town. But unlike a lot of similar places, it seems to be thriving. Despite the ever-ailing economy, there are very few boarded up shop-fronts, or â€˜To(i)Letâ€™ signs, and an acceptablly low proportion of vape-stores to other outlets. While there is â€“ of course â€“ a High Street, most of the usual chain-stores can be found in the adjacent Mill Gate shopping centre. If itâ€™s â€˜swag threadsâ€™ youâ€™re after, the lion share of designer outlets are in the swanky new retail precinct known as â€˜The Rockâ€™, which strikes me as a strange name for such a swish location â€“ itâ€™s no Alcatraz! Thereâ€™s also the world-famous Bury Market between the Bus Station (sory, â€˜Interchangeâ€™!) and Mill Gate, to cater for all your other shopping needs, if those happen to include bags, leather goods, or assorted meat products (including black pudding).

If itâ€™s retro games that tickle your fancy, you can avail yourself of the usual suspects. Thereâ€™s a CEX between the Mill Gate and the Market, and a Cash Generator on the High Street, where you might sometimes find a distressed SNES or Megadrive cart (wet wipes are your friends here, high-street retro outlets). Thereâ€™s also the ubiquitous Game in The Rock, where youâ€™ll no doubt be able to source the latest Evercade cart, or mini-console of choice. A more interesting option â€“ if you have the time â€“ is Victor Wright Electronics. And youâ€™ll certainly need time. While the selection of ancient electronics includes gadgets, gizmos, remote controls, video games â€“ and much more besides â€“ is huge, the filing system is, lets just say â€“ eccentric. Goodness knows whatâ€™s at the bottom of those heaps. But you could luck out.

Arcade Club, Ela Mill, Cork Street, Bury BL9 7BW

OK folks, Iâ€™m going to cut to the chase here. Come rain, wind, sleet, snow or sun, Arcade Club, Bury is hands down, without a doubt, by far the biggest and the best of the arcades of its type in Europe. I imagine you probably knew that already. For my money, it even beats Funspot NH, in the US and A â€“ for reasons Iâ€™ll come back to later. In fact, if it wasnâ€™t for a certain establishment in Brookfield, Illinois, I doubt thereâ€™s much to rival it in the entire world! According to the Arcade Club website, there are more than 400 classic and modern arcade machines, pinball tables, and games consoles on the floor!

The price of entry to this Aladdinâ€™s Cave of electronic entertainment? A mere Â£18 of your earth pounds per adult per session. That means Thursdays 4 to 11pm, Fridays 6pm to midnight (adults only) Saturdays 11 am to 11 pm and Sundays from 11am to 8pm. Opening hours are extended during the local school holidays, with discounts for kids, families, and season tickets. I bought a month ticket for my epic trip round Blackpool, Bury and Leeds, which worked out as a nice saving over the cost of four single entires. Given whatâ€™s on offer, Iâ€™d say it was a bargain.

I could easily spill a few thousands words describing the games in all their pixellated glory. But the truth is, the collection is just so big, so varied, and so constantly evolving, itâ€™d be an almost unending task â€“ the retro-games equivalent of painting the Forth Road Bridge! Besides, thereâ€™s such a huge and growing number of video walkrounds plastered all over the internet, that thereâ€™s not really much point. If you were being extra sensible when planning your trip, youâ€™d check if your favourite games were goingt o be out on the floor by browsing the online games catalogue, and e-mailing to ask which venue theyâ€™re currently in. You never know, if your favourite JAMMA pcb isnâ€™t in Bury, and you give them enough notice, they might be able to shuffle things about for your visit.

To avoid re-inventing the wheel, what I thought Iâ€™d do instead is focus on the layout and the feel of the place â€“ and offer a few tips on how best to enjoy it.

There are currently four floors to the Arcade Club experience at Bury â€“ a number which has doubled since its grand opening at Halloween 2015. From sharing its section of Ela Mill with several other businesses, the Club has gradually expanded to the point of sole occupancy and saturation of the building. You could say that Arcade Club, Bury, is now a giant â€˜family entertainment centreâ€™. But I would argue that the singularity of that description doesnâ€™t do the place justice. The Club, you see, is not simply one arcade. In 2024, itâ€™s at least five different arcades â€“ each with its own distinct flavour.

Compared to entertainment â€˜compoundâ€™ at Funspot, NH, it may have a smaller footprint. But as Iâ€™ve discussed in a previous post, only one small part of Funspot is given over to Golden-Age video games. The rest of its expansive acreage (!) is packed full of ticket-redemption machines and other distractions. The American Classic Arcade Museum certainly has its charms, and is well-worth a visit in its own right. Compared to The Club, however, it just doesnâ€™t have the numbers or the variety.

The most recent addition to Arcade â€˜complexâ€™ at Bury is on the ground floor. As you approach the reception to get your hand-stamped, you come face to face an all-new mini-arcade. I say â€˜miniâ€™, but by UK standards, the number of machines on the floor mean itâ€™s actually quite â€˜largeâ€™. In a way, it works as a showcase, giving a hint of the delights on offer further on and higher up in the venue. It hosts a small, but carefully curated seclection of classics, a few more-recent video games, a pool table, some rhythm games, and even a basket-ball machine â€“ something for everyone.

Moving up to the first floor, itâ€™s clear that the selection has been tailored towards the younger demographics, i.e. Arcade Club: The Next Generation. This is where youâ€™ll find the latest crowd-pleasers. From the absolutely-mahoosive Mission Impossible Super Deluxe, to Dark Escape 4D, Luigiâ€™s Mansion, Centipede Chaos and various other big-cab behemoths. Throw in some air hockey, basket-ball machines, and a tonne of interlinked Egg Boxes (snigger) and PS5s, and thereâ€™s everything you need to keep the yoof happy.

Onwards and upwards to the second floor is where youâ€™ll find the majority of The Clubâ€™s rhythm and dance games, a large selection of the best new and classic pinball tables, as well as a few choice candy cabs and woodies hosting a range of old favourites like Defender and Robotron. As the second floor is where Arcade Club hosts itâ€™s annual Defender Players Unite meets, there are, naturally, multiple examples of both. But thatâ€™s not all. The main hall on floor two boasts an ecclectic range of machines from the 80s, 90s and naughties. Nestled beside it, on the corridor leading to the stairs is a whole nother arcade! And itâ€™s nothing short of candy-cab central. This is by far the largest collection of Japanese sit-down cabinets Iâ€™ve ever seen in a British arcade. OK, so they were never that common over here back in the day, but even in more recent times, this collection has never to my knowledge been surpassed in terms of the size or range of games on offer. The cabinets are set-up for both vertical and horizontal play, and house so many â€˜bullet hellâ€™ shooters of the CAVE variety, that I dread to think what the insurance premiums must be.

These first three floors are great. Between them, they cater for all tastes â€“ from the smallest of kiddles, through the assembled ranks of casual gamers, to the most dedicated of arcade â€˜enthusiastsâ€™. But if your penchant is for classic arcade games from the 70s, 80s and 90s, youâ€™re going to want to head straight for the third floor. Here, at the beating heart or Arcade Club, is where youâ€™ll find its phenomenal collection of 200+ Golden-Age arcade games â€“ covering all the classics in both dedicated cabinets and the obligatory phallanx of Electrocoin Goliath JAMMA cabs.

As at Blackpool, the machines are in excellent condition. None have been retro-fitted with horrifically anachronistic LCDs. Better yet, the CRTs and controls are regularly checked, and tuned for the optimal gaming experience. Even the cabinet art is finessed, where appropriate, to really bring the machines back to life, with new but authentic control panel overalys adorning most of the Electrocoin machines.

For me, this is what makes Arcade Club, Bury the mothership. It is the embodyment of what Alan Meades â€“ author of Arcade Britannia â€“ calls the â€˜Mythic Arcadeâ€™ â€“ except, The Club isâ€¦ real? Well, thatâ€™s what I was going to say, but the more I think about it, the more it goes beyond what weâ€™ve learned to expect from reality.

If we compare Arcade Club to our memories of the arcades of yesteryear, itâ€™s actually â€˜hyper-realisticâ€™. It takes everything that was good and fun about those places, and doesnâ€™t just expand upon them, but blows them up to truly incredible proportions. Not one of us ever saw a collection as impressive as this back-in-the-day. They simply didnâ€™t exist. Yes, you would often see clusters of Goliath cabinets in a seaside arcade, sometimes even a couple of dozen in the one place, but you would never even hope to see 50 of them in one long row!

Neither did we see the same range of games in any one place at any one time. For the operators in the fast-moving world of video-arcades in the past, it was almost always out-with-the-old-in-with-the-new. At Arcade Club, you get to enjoy the best of all eras, and recreate you own personal journey through the classics as you remember it. In theory, thatâ€™s great. But therein lies a problem.

Top Tips

From its origins as a small-scale business experiment (which you can read about towards the end of this post), Arcade Club has grown into a large and successful operation. The Bury venue attracts many thousands of vistors a month â€“ sometimes a week. That means it can get busy. Thatâ€™s particularly true on Saturdays during the day â€“ when The Club has become a popular spot for families with smaller kids and childrensâ€™ parties. From what Iâ€™ve see, it can get pretty frantic in the early afternoon on all three floors â€“ but especially â€“ on floor one and the ground-floor arcade. So maybe save them for later on in your visit!

Having said that, evening sessions can also be packed, but not usually equally across all floors. In my experence, floors one and two â€“ which are more squarely aimed at the younger gamers â€“ seem to be the busiest. So, once again, maybe save your exploration of those parts of the building until later on in the evening when the crowds start to thin out. Donâ€™t get me wrong, the busy-ness brings a sense of life and vitality to the place, which really helps to build the ambience â€“ but if youâ€™re chasing hi-scores, it doesnâ€™t always create the best conditions.

What about floor three?

If your main reason for visiting Arcade Club is to indulge in the games of the Golden Age, the best time to go is Friday evening. Itâ€™s an adults only session, but tends to be quieter than the other floors anyway. Why is that? Perhaps itâ€™s an altitude thing? Maybe the younger revellers get filtered out as they move up through the higher levels? Or maybe itâ€™s got more to do with the types of game on offer. It doesnâ€™t really matter. But thereâ€™s something else that doesâ€¦

If you havenâ€™t been before, or donâ€™t go very often, the temptation will be to rush round looking for all the games you remember. Because theyâ€™re all on free-play, you wonâ€™t give a second thought to crediting up, or moving on if something else grabs you by the peripheral vision. Take it from me, even the most â€˜enthusiasticâ€™ of games is going to be overwhelmed by the variety of choice on offer!

OK, if itâ€™s your introduction to the place, and you know youâ€™re coming back soon, that not necessarily a bad thing â€“ but itâ€™s possibly not the best way to make the most of the experience. What Iâ€™d suggest is you make out a list of, say, 8-10 games and plan to have a few goes on each. Set yourself a hi-score challenge, or join in one of the online competitions like 10 Pence Arcade Podcast V2.0 and do it that way instead. And for goodness sake, do yourself a favour and install the amazing Arcade Sidekick App on your phone so you can record it properly. That way, you can ease yourself back into the nostalgia sphere, and enjoy the games at the same time. You know it makes sense.

Finally â€“ and bear with me here, because it might sound a bit weird â€“ if youâ€™re an aging gamer, and planning on an arcade marathon, you might want to take some training gloves to support your wrists. Alright, OK, settle down. Iâ€™m sure your wrists are used to a workout. What you might not realise until itâ€™s too late, however, is that underneath their shiney new overlays, Electrocoin Goliathâ€™s have mild steel control panels. And even when itâ€™s reasonably warm in the arcades, those steel control panels can stay cool or even cold â€“ which inevitably transfers to your wrists. You donâ€™t want to be risking carpal tunnel or sprained joints at your age, do you!

I forgot to take mine last time, which is when it struck me how ossum it would be if The Club sold them in its shop. What they need to do are some weight-lifting gloves with the AC logo emblazoned on the front. Iâ€™d buy them as a souvenier every time. Merch FTW, baby.

Food and drink

Arcade Club is an industry in itself. In addition to its five arcades, there are three bars and a shop, selling bar food, snacks and drinks â€“ of a soft, and boozaholic nature â€“ almost as fast as the staff can fetch them off the shelves. Like Blackpool, eveything on offer is of a good quality and reasonably priced. Unlike the other, smaller venues, as Arcade Club, Bury covers four floors, thereâ€™s also a lot more sit-down space to enjoy it. Take note, though: the large dining area on the third floor can get pretty rammed around lunchtime, so plan your eats accordingly!

If I had two very minor critiques, they would be this: Most people who visit The Club are there an afternoon out, or a party. And when youâ€™re doing that, party food is very much part of the expected package. With its burgers, hot-dogs, pizzas, and nachos, the Arcade Club Kitchen does this very well. I get that not many folks are there for extended stays, but when you are, with The Club being a fair schlepp from the town centre, itâ€™d be good if there were a few healthy alternatives on offer. Even just a selection of fruit. The same goes for the drinks. Both the range and the prices are great. Bottles of water are also available. But if youâ€™re there for a long day or a couple of days, youâ€™re gonna want to stay hydrated. Now, if The Club were to install some â€˜water stationsâ€™ (extra taps) and maybe start selling branded water bottles, thatâ€™d be a win-win situation.

Epilogue

When youâ€™ve been enjoying video arcade games for as long as I have â€“ when youâ€™ve lived through their heyday, lamented their demise, and spent decades seeking out the last living specimins in the wild â€“ simply knowing that a place like this exists, is a source of comfort.

Iâ€™ve already written about the almost spiritual importance of the CRT for the generation that grew up in the â€™70s and â€™80s. With its almost encyclopedic collection of historically important games, weâ€™d have no problems considering Bury to be a leading museum of video-arcade heritage. But this is no silent and still temple to the quiet contemplation of times past. Neither can it be seen as a â€˜necropolisâ€™, where old junk has been dumped to rot or get flogged to death. The machines are so well-looked after, and the place so buzzing with life and vitality, nothing could be further from the truth. I donâ€™t think it would be unreasonable to suggest that the place has religious significance. To really understand what I mean by that, youâ€™d have to visit. Visit for yourself, so you can enjoy it and reconnect with your arcadey roots. But visit to make sure it stays open, and the experience stays available to the wider gaming community as it powers its way into the future.

What are your thoughts on Arcade Club, Bury? What are your favourite games? Please feel free to leave a note in the comments below.

Next up: Arcade Club, Leeds!

Iâ€™ve been â€˜down Blackpoolâ€™ a fair few times over the years. When I think about it, my trips to the Lancashire Riviera have skimmed across the decades like a stone across a pond. To begin with, they were few and far between. More recently, theyâ€™ve come thick and fast. Or perhaps it just seems that way because of how old Iâ€™m getting?

My first visit to Blackpool was in 1977 on an ill-fated family holiday. I had not long turned 5. My parents, my younger brother, and me had taken the train down from Glasgow to stay in a guest house. It wasnâ€™t like the BBCâ€™s fictional Seaview with its high-larious haul of 7 Space Invaders machines (S01E03). Nor was it run by a young Yvette Fielding. The reality was a small, top-floor flat owned and managed by a grumpy old man. Am I being mean? Well, I wouldnâ€™t like to suggest his fizzog turned the milk, but not long after arriving, we were all stricken by such explosive food poisoning, that we had to be rescued by a relative. Being the â€™70s, there were no problems squeezing 5 passengers into a car designed for 4. Seatbelts were an optional inconvenience in those days. Fortunately, we survived both the lurgy, and the trip home, even if we didnâ€™t see much of Blackpool that wasnâ€™t toilet-shaped ðŸ˜¦

But thatâ€™s not how this story ends.

Before the decade was out, young Odysseus had returned to â€˜see the lightsâ€™, experience the assault on the senses that was the Golden Mile, and visit the legendary Pleasure Beach. Were arcade video games a part of that picture? Youâ€™d better believe they were!

Sadly â€“ as we all know â€“ the shape of Blackpoolâ€™s arcade landscape â€“ or arcadscape (c) if you will â€“ has changed a lot since those halcyon days. And not for the better. In fact, if it wasnâ€™t for the triumphant return of the CRT to the former Casino at 74 Bloomfield Road, its phosphor glow would already have flickered out. Thatâ€™s right, folks. As youâ€™ve probably already guessed, the final destination of todayâ€™s blogpost will be the latest addition to the Palmersâ€™ Arcade-Club Empire â€“ which will also serve as a starting point for my reviews of all three venues!!!

Before we hit â€˜The Clubâ€™, however, weâ€™ll get ourselves warmed up with a look around Blackpool and environs as they are now, checking out itâ€™s other video-gaming delights in the process. Itâ€™d be rude not to. Weâ€™ll also nod a wink to the arcades of summers past with a comparison of my photos and arcade experiences from the last 10 years with some nostalgia-soaked shots from the archives. What more could you want?!

Stoppinâ€™ at â€˜Services for Photos

Todayâ€™s story begins at 70 mph on the M74.

Iâ€™ve been up an down that road many times since 1977.

For the first decade or two it was always as a passenger. Growing up in central Scotland, my familyâ€™s pursuit of the summer sun usually involved long road trips to the south. Unless the destination was somewhere down the East Coast of England, they would usually also include a long stretch on the M6.

Of course, the roads themselves have changed over the years. After what feels like decades of â€˜improvementsâ€™, the section passing Carlisle is a lot less prone to traffic jams than it was. Thatâ€™s not to say it isnâ€™t busy. In fact, once you pass the border, the traffic seems to spawn as if from some kind of arcade monster generator.

The M74 is still much quieter. But where once were views of serene emptiness is now an industrial landscape of mostrous wind turbines, whose massive concrete footings have permenantly scarred the bens and braes. Thank goodness that floating turbines are now a reality that can be kept out of sight, and easily removed if and when we come up with a better way to generate electrickery.

But I digress.

Once Iâ€™d finished tilting at windmills, it struck me that I was sitting at the helm of a red Vauxhall Zafira. Some folks, including my own son, donâ€™t have much time for that brand of vehicle. Iâ€™ve heard it likened to a skip in lipstick. That always makes me laugh. In my mind, itâ€™s easily closer to Magnumâ€™s Testosteronza.

In all seriousness, though, I actually like the colour. I always have done. I thought that was for aesthetic reasons. But perhaps it was sub-conscious nostalgia for those ancient summer journeys that drove me to choose it.

You see, from about 1980, the carriage de jour in our family was a red Ford Cortina! What a car! It was both spacious and well-equipped. The stunning analogue sound system (an AM radio) worked during the day and at night. The sophisticated air-con facilities (roll-down windows) provided a choice of hot or deafeningly windy. Oh the fun we had, after hours in a sticky traffic jam, peeling our sweaty backs off the seats.

Or maybe not.

Naturally, my parents were keen to avoid that kind of thing on our summer road trips â€“ and the inevitable squabbling it caused in the back seat.

By the mid-80s, they had perfected their solution. By the afternoon of the last day of the school in late June, our wee caravan â€“ an Eccles Topaz no less â€“ would be prepped, packed and ready to roll. But we werenâ€™t quick to leave. Nossir, weâ€™d wait until after tea to skip rush hour and beat the traffic. That was a sensible move 40 years ago. If they were heading into the chaos Iâ€™ve seen on the M62 recently, they might not have left the drive at all!

Of course, even in the 1980s it wasnâ€™t all plain-sailing.

Letâ€™s face it, driving through the night is never much fun when its part of a holiday. But when you were a kid in the back seat, there were some perks. Staying up late listening to the radio was one of them. Simpler times, eh? The other was when my parents pulled in at a service station for a break, or even a snooze. Because then my brother and me could buy ourselves a â€˜grab-bagâ€™ sized packet of Hula-Hoops, and hit the arcade!

There were no Motos or Welcome Breaks in those days. No Greggs, McDonalds or Costas either. The big names included (Top) Rank, part of the J Arthur Rank Foundation famous for its films, Granada, which also turned its hand to TV production, and Trusthouse Forte, who were perhaps better known for their hotel chain. Further down the A1, you might have enjoyed a break at a Blue Boar location. For a wealth of info and photos on this stuff, check out https://motorwayservices.uk

Our first stop would usually be Granadaâ€™s services at Southwaite in Cumbria, or â€“ if the going was good â€“ Rankâ€™s Forton facilities in Lancashire. Both were much of a muchness in my recollection, with well-stocked newsagents on both carriageways and â€“ more importantly â€“ arcades all round. Iâ€™m not talking about a couple of battered chip-shop cabinets here either. Itâ€™s easy to forget just how vibrant the arcade scene was in these places back in the 80s. Collections of 10 or 12 cabs or more werenâ€™t unusual. There were always at least a couple of the most up-to-date games. And they were always busy too â€“ whether it was 2 in the afternoon or 2 in the morning! Happy days!

Southwaite was where I first encountered the mighty Gauntlet on the way back home in 1986. On the way south, in 1987, it was where I first saw Karnov and Alien Syndrome. So what, you might ask? Karnov isnâ€™t particularly well-known, and doesnâ€™t exactly have the best of reputations. The thing is, though, while we were waiting to set off that day, Iâ€™d spent the afternoon reading the latest edition of Computer and Video Games magazine. And, obviously, in anticipation of the pixelated escapades that lay in front of me, Iâ€™d fixated on the â€˜Arcade Actionâ€™ section. As you can see from the images below, those were the two headline games that month. Somehow Iâ€™d felt sure theyâ€™d be at the services, and lo, it came to pass. Wow! Maybe Iâ€™d â€˜actualisedâ€™ the experience? You know? Like what that Jim Carey talks about on the YouTubes?

My memories of Forton are a bit hazier. Looking back, that makes perfect sense. In the early 80s, the place was filled with cigarette smoke. But when the smog lifted, itâ€™s where I first saw classics like Centipede and Gorf. Itâ€™s also where â€“ in 1981 â€“ my Granny, who was holidaying with us that year, bought us a copy of the wonderful Trigan Empire compendium. The story is basically â€˜Romans in outer spaceâ€™, but the artwork, by Don Lawrence, is really something else â€“ like a 1950s swords and sandals movie, but rendered in paint. Itâ€™s stunning, and well-worth a butchers.

The New Frontier Arcade, Haslingden, Lancashire, August 2014

At every Arcade Club, thereâ€™s something for everyone, no matter their taste in gaming. Greetings fellow travellers!

If youâ€™re reading this blog, you probably like old video games. I know I do! Especially those of the arcade variety. Theyâ€™ve been an important part of my life for nigh on half-a-century (Yeah, Iâ€™m that old!). You know the score.

To reconnect with the â€˜Golden Ageâ€™ of arcade or home gaming, you really need the â€˜equitmentâ€™.

Inevitably, my stash of vintage gaming equipment has grown to include a selection of old computers, consoles, and TVs. Not so many that Iâ€™m in danger of getting showcased â€“ in Retro Gamer magazine â€“ or one of those â€˜hoardingâ€™ documentaries! But I do seem to have acquired a modest collection of stuff.

As a naturally tidy person, I kept most of it stored away in the loft, rotating things out every now and again as time permitted. Starting about 2016, however, I was also bitten by the console-revival-bug that started with the NES, C64, and SNES minis. Perhaps not surprisingly, they proved to be rather popular.

Fast-forward to the Christmas holidays in 2018, and a dinner with friends â€“ and the topic of video-games events came up.

Why?

Our local library had been dumped by the coonsil, only to be saved at the last minute by a community group. Events were needed to encourage folks, especially kids, to keep coming into the building on a regular basis â€“ hopefully to borrow and read some books! But keeping the venue open wasnâ€™t cheap, so fundraising was important too.

Various suggestions were on the table, mostly on the kind of book-related themes you might expect. But as the bleeps and bloops in the background began to escalate, it seemed that we had another potential solution staring us right in the ears. What about a Retro Games Club? The idea appeared to have wings. A few weeks of discussion, photoshopping and printing later and I had a plan.

In todayâ€™s post, I want to share my experience of running a Retro Games Club. Iâ€™ll cover what we did, how we did it, and how long it all took. That way, if you ever take the notion of running a club of your own, you can side-step the logistical problems, and start with the dial wanged all the way round to 11!

Gathering the troops

If youâ€™ve got enough stuff, enough time and enough energy, itâ€™s perfectly possible to set up and run a retro games club on your own. If you can remember back to the glory days of the JAMMA+ forum, youâ€™ll probably know about the legendary efforts of Mr RGP (Retro Games Party), which have since blossomed into a bona fide business model.

For my humble project, however, the idea was to get the local community involved â€“ to spread the joy, but also the load. Being of a certain age (old) was pretty useful here. With a few of my friends also harbouring retro-gaming urges, there would be a range of hands on deck. As we were all dads, we also had a ready made constituency of mini-gamers to help get the party started.

So far, so good.

Between us, we had a pile of retro kit â€“ but that didnâ€™t mean we could just plug it all in and get started. The venue was now run as a charity, and the terms of its insurance meant that electronics equipment had to be P.A.T. tested. With some of this stuff being 40 years old, and some of it accumulating 1000s of Volts, it was important that we didnâ€™t expose the public, or the building, to any unnecessary risks. Even more so when kids would be involved. For an extra layer of saftey â€“ and convenience â€“ we also decided to run most of the stuff via fused extension cables. That meant absolutely tonnes of stuff had to get tested. If weâ€™d had it done privately, it would have cost a bomb. Fortunately, a member of the Committee was a registered electrician, who gave up an evening to do it for free. If you need to get this done yourself, itâ€™s worth checking if any local sparkies will do a special rate for charities. Iâ€™ve heard of some that will do it for a pound a test â€“ although even at that rate you could be looking at Â£50 or more for a half-decent selection of gear!

Planning the event

With the equitment gathered, tested, and ready to go, the next big step was to advertise the first event. Before we could do that, however, we had to figure out what the format would be.

The main thing â€“ obviously â€“ was being able to offer a wide range of systems and games. But we also wanted to avoid the â€˜tyranny of choiceâ€™, where the limitless selections of multi-carts can isolate gamers from each other, and quickly lead to boredom. The more sessions we ran, the more obvious it became that optimum levels of fun were generated by paring back the selection of games as much as possible â€“ essentially running every system as a dedicated arcade cabinet.

Rather than simply turning on the machines and leaving the visitors to it, we decided to have a couple of systems fitted with multi-carts, but for most to be running a single competition game â€“ with high scores getting listed on a white board, and prizes awarded to the winners.

In terms of competition games, we had to think pretty carefully about the selection on offer.

Lots of folks have very fond memories of obscure old games â€“ and while we were keen to accommodate those nostalgia trips where possible, we were also conscious that they wouldnâ€™t always make the best games for quick plays or competitions.

The winning formula turned out to be pretty straightforward. Games should be simple, easy to learn, have a clear scoring mechanism, and not last very long â€“ allowing the maximum number of people to have a go, and to encourage a bit of competition. Games like Frogger, Galaxian, and Chuckie Egg fit the bill rather nicely.

Nowadays, there are also a bunch of amazing home-brew games for the C64, including the awesome Canabalt, and the 4K phenomena Winky Blinky and Dog that make for really great competitions. If you havenâ€™t seen them, be sure to check â€™em out!

I already had a whiteboard and pens we could use for high scores. A few shifts on GIMP later, and we had some information boards for the machines, some labels highlighting the prize games, and some certificates for the winners. Kids love that kind of thing!

Given that the club was going to involve a long stretch on Saturday afternoons, we reckoned that there should also be snacks. First thoughts were the kind of comfort snacks we remembered from our own youth â€“ donuts, crisps, and coca cola. All the good stuff! But as responsible, community-minded adults, we also had to be sensible. Healthy snacks (apples!) would also be available, as would gluten and sugar-free alternatives. There would also be some water, coffee and â€“ of course â€“ biscuits for the grown-ups. All of this would come at a cost, which would have to be covered by the ticket price. While the ultimate goal was to raise some money for the library on top of this, we didnâ€™t want to price anyone out.

Compromises had to be reached.

Luckily, the best donuts on the market (street), could be had for 11p each in packs of 5. Crisps werenâ€™t much more. And at the time, cans of coke (full-fat and sugar free) were south of 30p a tin (if bought in mahoosive boxes). Figure in some packets of gummi-type sweets for prizes, the fruit, and the gluten and sugar-free snack alternatives, and we found that we could cater for about 80p a head. That was assuming that this wouldnâ€™t be a one-off event, and that the remainder of any bulk-buys could be held over to the next event. Setting the ticket price at Â£2 including snacks seemed like good value, and would still generate some cash for the library. I imagine youâ€™d have to raise that to Â£3 or more nowadays to achieve the same kind of results.

Letting the world know

The plan was to let people pay on the door. But to encourage folks to buy into the event in advance, I also rustled up some souvenir tickets. If youâ€™re going to do this kind of thing yourself, youâ€™re going to need a paper guillotine. Cutting them out with scissors is a pain in the proverbials.

The final hurdle was letting the world know. To do that, we needed some posters.

The design of the posters was deliberately cluttered (honest!) â€“ partly for ironic reasons, but mostly to give the intended audience something to explore, and hopefully to find something specific to identify with. Something to hook them in. We posted them on relevant and specifically-targetted web-platforms and â€˜socialsâ€™. For extra-added old-skool charm, they were also printed out, laminated, and pinned up on notice boards around the village!

After the first few, I decided to beef up the retro-chic-quotient by adding some 80s icons.

Eventually, the temptation to riff off (rip off?!) the kidsâ€™ favourite TV show was just too hard to resist.

And once you go down that road, the challenge of matching branding, fonts and styling sets you sliding down the slippery road towards addiction.

In the end, things started getting a bit out of hand!

Let battle commence!

As you can see from the posters, the Club had its premier on the 20th of April 2019. Thatâ€™s five whole years ago! Happy Birthday â€˜Retro Games Clubâ€™!

Getting everything ready that first Saturday morning took ages.

Moving my own stuff from its various hidee-holes at home into the boot of the car took about an hour. This was on top of the hour it had already taken to go to the shops to buy the scran, and make up some flasks of coffee for the grown ups.

From parking the car outside the venue to being fully green-lit and ready to go took another 45 minutes â€“ and that was with several other people helping to get the boxes in, unpack the stuff, and set it all up. Getting everything dimantled, back into the boot, and finally stowed away at the end of the day took another 90 minutes. So, basically, with a 1 pm start in mind, the shenanigans had to get underway by about 10 am. The 5 pm finish meant that tea could not be eaten, nor hostelries visited before about 6.30 pm. Thatâ€™s quite a shift for the old day off!

After a few sessions, it was clear that a later start time would be needed to let us get things ready at a less frantic pace. It also meant we had time for some lunch before the guests arrived. Noice.

Retro-games clubbing!

Running the Club was definitely not a one-man job.

In fact, youâ€™ll want a sensible number of adults for the size of the intended audience. A ratio of about 1 to 10 is usually a good idea. But youâ€™ll need to make sure that at any given time, the whole area can be looked over by adults whoâ€™ve gone through the appropriate background checks. In Scotland, that means a DBS (Disclosure Scotland) check. The easiest thing to do here is to get someone involved who already works with kids (eg. as a school teacher, teaching assistant, nursery teacher etc.), or who is involved with a childrensâ€™ group, like the Scouts or the Boysâ€™ Brigade. Teachers will already have one, paid for by their employer â€“ as will most folks who are regular contributors to kidsâ€™ groups. Depending on the size of the venue, one might be enough. The best thing to do is check the rules and requirements with the venue itself. They may well have a list of certified volunteers who can come along for the day and help out. Fortunately, we had all those bases covered between us.

We needed someone at the front desk to meet, greet, explain what was happening, and make sure that high scores were recorded accurately. We also needed bods in circulation to keep an eye on the kids, and the machines (!), and to check that everything stayed on and working. Itâ€™s amazing how easily kids can crash RPi set-ups â€“ even when theyâ€™ve been certified bomb-proof by adults.

With the snacks, rather than leaving everything out on a table and having folks help themselves, we decided to have a dedicated snack-time about half-way through. Two adults minimum were needed to hand out the goods, and make sure that the inevitable debris was quickly and suitably recycled. Those kids went at the donuts and crisps like a shoal of piranhas! Cloths, kitchen roll, disinfectant spray, and binbags were on hand in case of catastrophe. We also decided to give guests a time-warning at 4.30, and to use the last 10 minutes for anouncing the competition-winners and awarding the prizes.

How did it all work out?

In short, it was BRILLIANT!

That first day â€“ which we ran as a test â€“ had about 20 paying guests. More would have been better. But in retrospect the limited nmbers were a good thing. It gave us the space we needed to iron out the creases and nail down the routine. After that, word spread, with the number of paying guests doubling to around 40 for the next event, and passing 50 by the end of November.

The growing numbers inspired an adults-only event between Christmas and New Year, with beer and cake, as well as coke and donuts. I have to say, it looked pretty good fun, even if I was lumped with responsible person status!

Game Over?

By late February 2020, weâ€™d got into a bit of a rhythm. The Retro-Games Club was taking off as a local event. The vibe was good, the kids had fun, and weâ€™d raised several hundred pounds for the library.

Plans for a follow-up event at the end of March were well underway whenâ€¦

Well, we all know what happened in March 2020.

It was late 2022 before we were in a position to think about a revival.

By that point, the pooled retro-collections, Rpi-creations, and TV stock-pile had grown. Iâ€™d managed to bag a few extra CRTs through a local advertising campaign (!), and was keen to get them fired up and running clasic video games.

Unfortunately, in the years that had passed since our last event, the libraryâ€™s buildings insurance had been changed to one that seemed to require full PAT-testing for every single piece of electrical equipment being used. While that seems sensible for high-voltage kit, like CRT TVs, Iâ€™m not so sure itâ€™s necessary for very low-power gear like RPis. I also â€˜hae ma dootsâ€™ that blasting aging PC Engines or Vectrexes (Vectrices?) with a test jolt is the best thing for their electronic health. To my mind, the regulations would allow for (partial) exceptions for this kind of equipment, especially if other layers of saftey precaution were put in place. But that doesnâ€™t mean the insurance company needs to agree!

Epilogue

If I can find a way to spare my geriatric electronics the indignity of shock-testing, Iâ€™d be up for reviving the Retro Games Club. An alternative might be to restrict the event to less valuable and less-cherished relics, like RPi-based systems and LCD screens. Would that cut the mustard? Maybe some of the dads would still come along. But in the life of the kids who used to visit the Club, 5 years is a very long time. The ones who still play video games have moved on to more modern things. Some of them have left home and moved away. Would an even younger crowd be interested in our Stone Age appliances? Watch this space. Weâ€™ll have to wait and seeâ€¦

Werenâ€™t arcade games brilliant?

I mean, they werenâ€™t just games. They were a full-on sensory workout! You got retina-searing colours, synapse-tingling jingles, and the chance to spray your digital territory with crudely miss-spelt memos in instalments of 3 letters: XYZ IZA D*K anyone? Remember that? Amazing!

Where I want to go with this is home computers, people. Because theyâ€¦.. were GLORIOUS!

My original plan for this post was to begin chronicling my journey through the world of personal computers, starting with the ZX Spectrum. But thereâ€™s already so much copy out there â€“ so many websites, blogposts, Youtube videos, and podcasts that do such a brilliant job of showcasing the systems and the games, that it all seemed a bit redundant.

While I might come back to some of my favourite games in the future, what I thought Iâ€™d do instead is focus on the times and places that were central to my own 8-bit era. I thought it would be nice to take you back with me on a journey through the sights, the scenery, and the shenanigans of a typical 1980s shopping mall â€“ to help you reconnect with the Golden Age in all its beige, brown and orange splendour.
